Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I thought that was the question investigators are asking and testing. Yes. The question brought up by Another if I read it right is he is concerned about slowing it down. The study says It is probably not masking PSA it is slowing progression of disease down. I would agree that masking it is bad. I myself want to slow it down and kick the can down the road. Is that good? I think so. If not why not just go find foods that feed the cancer (if there are such foods) so you can see sooner if it is there.

Posts.Title: RALP in 20 hours

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Another My concern has always been it's affect on PSA when true values are critical, such as testing for BCR. A surgeon may have less investment in that question than the RO/MO. Good questions. Most of the study refers to men on AS or WW. They pointed out that there was some assurance that reduction in PSA is linked to disease status. Is there a difference for men on AS delaying treatment by slowing disease progression and a man who is delaying more treatment after the primary treatment fails? Maybe in my case with a 4+3 diagnosed I would want to hit it as soon as possible. Then again any rise in PSA after prostate removal is probably not just a 3+3. But what about RT as primary? Are you in kind of an AS mode after RT and it is good slowing it down. Probably, because the next treatment modes are not desirable. A lot of questions as usual. I know one thing. I don't want my eating habits to help the cancer along. I would rather it be a slow moving target when it hits the BCR level. Can I slow it down with the right diet and keeping my body healthy? Maybe. I will probably never know.

Posts.Title: How do I learn to be patient/less stressed while waiting months for diagnostic info?

Posts.Content: You can have that discussion but you will find that there is a study or "famous" doctor out there to support ones position if you look hard enough. Dates on studies mean nothing unless you have the expertise to review them. I have never seen anyone here that can peer review these studies. If someone knows of a study or opinion that differs just point it out and provide a link. No one will take offense at someone providing more information. Assigning motives is ad hominem and not up to the standards of everyone who posts here.

Posts.Title: 1st post-prostatectomy PSA results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Brachytherapy had an 82 percent recurrence-free rate, which would make it clearly superior. I agree BT is a good option and not picking on you but if someone does not go read the whole article they would miss the point that this study is biased toward a better outcome for BT. As stated in their paper. Although this study analyzed a large cohort of patients, there are significant limitations. These include the single center retrospective nature of it leading to the obvious selection bias, and the fact that the BT patients probably had less aggressive disease due to the lower Gleason 7 percentage of patients. Furthermore, only 0.6% of RP patients received ADT compared to much high number in the radiotherapy patients. Additionally, no data is given on the duration of ADT. No significant difference was shown between patients treated with EBRT and RP, similarly to other large prospective published studies.

Posts.Content: When I had my consults with the RO he had 3 centers I could go to. He said he would not send me to the one closest because it had an older machine and they only use it to target secondary bone cancers. ( I got the term right now DjinTonic I think :>) So I know I have to see what machine is being used. Anyway, as we talked I found out the doctors don't operate the machine. The Radiation therapists do. Do you have to check them out like we do the surgeons? Or are they all good enough that it does not matter. Hopefully I will not have bcr but I always wondered about this since my talk with the RO.

Posts.Title: Amazing how ones perspective can change!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic I assume Ed is covering his bases in the case of BCR. I certainly hope so because I, too, had 5% involvement and the very same post-PR report and staging as Ed, but I had a G9 (4+5), and we agreed not to do anything unless we encounter BCR. Question for Ed and all you RALP guys -- did any of your surgeons do intra-operative frozen sections to see whether there was EPE and, if not, continue the operation and spare both nerve bundles? Yeh, I am OK and no radiation has been talked about. But we were talking about radiation in another thread and it brought back to my mind my surprise that the RO's were not involved with the treatment but they monitor it and I wondered how would I know if the guy/gal operating the machine was newly trained or experienced at it and does it matter. I guess I should put this out of my mind but a PSA test every 3 months reminds me. Getting cancer kind of makes you feel vulnerable at times. As to the intra-operative frozen sections, I don't know but I will ask him my next visit. I asked him before the operation if he checked the tissue as he was operating and he said yes. I didn't ask how he checked it. My question and his answer could have meant a lot of different things. Fail on my part to understand what I was asking.

Posts.Content: Brachytherapy: Where Has It Gone? An article by Kavanagh et al1 in a recent special issue of the Journal of Clinical Oncology highlighted several emerging technologies, translational frontiers, and novel clinical paradigms in radiation oncology. In the excitement generated by the plethora of these powerfully sophisticated tools now available to radiation oncologists, brachytherapy is often mistakenly viewed as an antiquated or even irrelevant modality, despite the central role it continues to play in the management of several cancer types. Further, having undergone its own remarkable recent technological advancement, brachytherapy continues to expand its potential application to a variety of clinical circumstances. There are several reasons for the decline in prostate brachytherapy. First, there was an increase in the number of robotic prostatectomies. Surgery accounted for approximately 44% of treatments before the introduction of robotic prostatectomy in the early 2000s and then rose to 60% in 2010.2 Second, there was an increase in the technical sophistication of EBRT, including intensity-modulated radiotherapy (IMRT), stereotactic radiotherapy (SBRT), and proton therapy. For prostate cancer, there has been a near-complete transition from the use of conventional EBRT to IMRT over the past decade from 0.15% in 2000 to 95.9% in 2008. Third, reimbursement for IMRT is markedly higher compared with that for brachytherapy. This and other factors have led to the development of urologist-owned centers focused exclusively on delivering IMRT for prostate cancer.12 The fourth reason is negative press, a result of cases of poor-quality prostate brachytherapy procedures leading to adverse clinical outcomes.13 Fifth, the volume of prostate brachytherapy procedures used to train radiation oncology residents is suboptimal. http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200/jco.2014.59.8128

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by MoeDeLawn If I do get bad news, my thought is to go back to my family doctor and review the pathology report with him, ask his opinion of the finding and whether he thinks I should seek a 2nd opinion from another urologist. Does that make sense in your experience -- did you go with your biopsy doctor's suggestion for treatment right away, or did you seek other input? Moe Hi Moe, If you get bad news and hopefully that is a big if, your doctor sent you to a urologist because you need a specialist. if you want a 2nd opinion on the path report get it from another urologist or 2 more if you want. Your the boss. It's kinda like your getting your oil changed and the guy tells you he hears something and he's not sure what is causing the noise but you should get to the dealer and have it checked out. You thank the guy and maybe let him know later how it worked out. Good news is the doctor that did the biopsy isn't taking any chances and sent those samples off to Johns Hopkins. Sound like a good guy. Hopefully the report is good. There are a lot of things other than cancer that can be the cause of your PSA rise and cells that look a little off. Was this a first PSA or has it been rising? Anyway, I know this is not the forum you wanted to sign into but we're glad you found us and I am sure others will be chiming in with their opinions. Take care , oh yeah, it took a few minutes to catch that name. I am really slow sometimes. (at least I hope it's a screen name, I should talk) Ed

Posts.Title: First Post -- Awaiting 2nd opinion on biopsy and a few questions

Posts.Content: I think you will find out as many ways to figure this out as there are people posting here. Be that as it may here is how I did it. 1. I had a partin table chance of confinement of 35%. Not good. But the DRE was neg and so was the ultrasound so I figured the 35% was low and so did the doctor who told me he believed the tables were out of date and he thought it was more like 50%. Even at 35% the risk/reward was high if it was confined and all removed. I felt radiation would be better if it had escaped. 2. I met with the RO twice to get answers to questions and was impressed with him and the technology. HD Brachy and EBRT on some pretty new machines. 3. I concluded either surgery or radiation would probably do the job. Why did I choose surgery? 1. I did not want to wait the time it took to get started for radiation. I felt time was important with the 95% biopsy core if I wanted any chance of the cancer being confined. Everyone says, "oh you have time". Fine, but there is a day, a point in time, that it escapes and I did not want to get to that day if I hadn't already. 2. I liked the RO but I really had and have a lot of trust in the Uro doctor. 3. I did not like the idea of never knowing what was exactly going on. With a post op path report I would have a better idea. 4 I do not physically react well to radiation scans and thought it might be a lot worse with the high doses I would be getting. 5. Last but most important to us. We prayed about it and felt surgery was the way forward. I don't know if any of this will help you but it will give you some insight and maybe you will read some things you did not consider as other people post. It was not the most important decision I have had to make and not really the hardest. But it was up there in the top 10. Ed

Posts.Title: Headed For Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: Roger, Sorry you have to be here but you have found a good place to talk with some great people, as you probably know if you have been reading the posts. You probably can't get surgery after radiation. It is done, but rare and only by a few doctors in the country when it is feasible to do. But remember surgery alone does not equal the cure rate of radiation. You have to throw in the guys that need radiation afterwards. It's not like you have surgery and you have an equal chance of a cure. And then you have radiation in your back pocket for an even better chance. Good luck and keep us posted. I know others will be dropping in to say hello. Ed

Posts.Title: Pretty sure I am going with hormones + EBT

Posts.Content: Yes, children will benefit from eating good food. This quote is from The National Center for Biotechnology Information. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC526387/ "Also, prostate cancer risk was found to be reduced by cruciferous vegetable consumption in a population-based case-control study carried out in western Washington state. Three or more servings per week, compared to less than one serving of cruciferous vegetables per week resulted in a statistically significant 41% decrease in prostate cancer risk" None of these foods cures cancer but they do a lot of good in preventing it. Do they help recurrence? No studies I found looked at that. Can't hurt eating healthy though.

Posts.Title: Still a Member

Posts.Content: I got a UTI after the operation. They can start in the bladder also. They did a urine test to confirm I had a UTI. But the test was very basic and when the results from the lab returned a couple of days later they called me and had me get another prescription for the type of bacteria identified. Didn't they give you an anti-biotic? I don't think it goes away by itself. Anyways it's not a big deal and you should not have a problem once cleared up.

Posts.Title: My Story and decision time

Posts.Content: I have had to mostly work on my core. Dead bug exercise, planks, etc. Just take it easy till the doc gives you the OK. For me it took more out of me than than my body felt. If I went by how I felt I could try to pick up that 80# trailer tongue and put it on the hitch. I would probably have a hernia now if I tried so I had to hold back on doing what I normally did until the healing was further along. I knew it had weakened me because I had lower back pain probably from a weakened core which is getting resolved now and a 10 mile bike ride kicked my butt.

Posts.Title: Preparing for intervention

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by tok718 What are the usual steps to take after the urologist informs patient cancer was found ? I’m looking for some advice and guidance. Thank you in advance -Anthony Anthony, I don't normally answer peoples first posts because there are others here that know a lot more than I do. But it is late and you sound very worried. First, prostate cancer is most of the time slow growing and the first steps you and your father need to take are getting informed about the disease and the treatment options. You have time. There are books in a sticky above and the one by Patrick Walsh is highly recommended by people here. When a urologist informs a patient that he has cancer it is usually a shock and you don't know what questions to ask and I think some doctors are not good in dealing with a patient in that initial meeting. Your father should get a copy of that pathology report and all tests performed. On the report will be a staging of the cores. It will be something like 3+3 or 3+4 etc. People here will not be able to give much advice without those numbers. The psa of 8 is high but is not over 10 which kicks it up to another level of concern. This all depends on the gleason score though. The urologist will normally have you meet with a radiation oncologist as an alternative to surgery. If the cancer has grown outside the prostate radiation may be the best choice but a psa of 8 sounds like it is still contained and he has options. You can of course change doctors to ones closer if that is better for your father. If you could tell the guys here what area your father lives in there may be people here that know the hospitals and doctors in that area. Others will chime in with more questions and advice but for now take a deep breath. I know this is tough but as you learn more over the next few weeks you and your father will be able to see some daylight and make the choices needed. It is good you are going to the meetings because a second set of ears is a big help. My wife went to all my meetings and reminded me of things I did not hear. Others will post and probably give you more advice and have more questions for you. Stay tuned. Ed

Posts.Title: Question for my father pc, lost , confused

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by OldTiredSailor I am trying to buy a Melges MC Scow, which is a 16-foot serious racing sailboat. It is designed for one or two people and requires the operator to put their feet under straps on the centerline and lean back, way back, outside the boat to keep the boat on a 17 degree heel when sailing hard upwind in more than 10-knots. It is a strenuous exercise, which I have been doing for 35+ years, but she was very worried that I would buy the boat, have my gut cut open, and then not be able to sail the boat for six months to a year... Surgery will weaken your abdomen muscles and risk an inguinal hernia until you heal. No matter how good a shape you are in they are slicing through your muscles that hold your insides in place and it needs to heal. Ask your doctor when he would expect you to be able to hike on that boat. Every doctor is different. Mine was way cautious and weight restrictions were very strict for 5 months. The nurse navigator freaked when I told her I was riding my bike 4 weeks after the surgery. But reading other guys posts they were much less strict. I would be surprised if he would approve of that kind of physical exertion in less than 2 months, but who knows. Having said all that. You have a ways to go before you have to ponder treatment for more than a couple of minutes a day if at all. And hopefully you get to skip the treatment part. Good luck with the biopsy. Mine was like most peoples here. Not much of anything. I jammed my thumb a week ago when I flipped my boat and that has been more uncomfortable than the biopsy was. Ed

Posts.Title: 4K test useful for deciding not to get biopsy?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by BS414 I went to Memorial Sloan Kettering for a second opinion from a medical oncologist. She agreed with my doctor for the same reasons, risks of surgery vs. benefits of radiation and hormonal therapy. If it were me with your history I would go with radiation. I went with surgery but I was on the edge of choosing radiation. If I had your stats I would have had radiation. HD brachy combined with EBRT was what was proposed. You have those 4+4 and 4+5s and radiation is showing to have a good record with high risk cases. Plus you are getting advice from a top notch center which is really great to have access to.

Posts.Title: Additional MRI Images - so scared now

Posts.Content: Michael is right. I have read that it is a 1 gm to 1 cc conversion for all practicable purposes. Just looked it up to be sure. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20653780 Abstract AIMS: Prostate gland volume is generally assessed by transrectal ultrasound examination or magnetic resonance imaging at the time of prostatic biopsy or pre-brachytherapy planning. The volume is most commonly measured using the formula, prostate volume = height x width x length x pi/6, which is derived considering the gland as ellipsoid. There are conflicting data regarding the accuracy of this method, with most studies comparing this calculated volume with that measured radiologically using planimetry with summation of sequential area measurements. The aim was to determine the relationship between prostate gland volume and weight. METHODS AND RESULTS: The accuracy of prostate gland volume calculated from three-dimensional measurements of the gland in 20 radical prostatectomy specimens relative to the true gland volume determined using water displacement was prospectively evaluated. Since volume measurement by water displacement is not practical in routine practice, the relationship between prostate weight and volume was also evaluated. Our findings indicate that the calculated gland volume consistently underestimates the true volume. The volume of the prostate gland (in cm(3)) very closely correlates with its weight (in g). CONCLUSIONS: The weight of the prostate gland (without the seminal vesicles) is an excellent surrogate for prostate volume. The prostate gland in radical prostatectomy specimens should be weighed after transecting the seminal vesicles at the base

Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Tim, I was in the hospital a couple of extra days. One for nausea and then they thought they saw something on my ekg so another day of blood tests and observation. I did not sleep on the recliner but I did sleep on the couch kind of sitting up. Took about 4 days until I felt comfortable laying down in the bed. My stomach was sensitive to most food. A lot of pain, I think from gas. I could drink coconut milk and eat yogurt. It took me 3 days to start eating solid food. No bladder problems and was continent from the time they removed the catheter. I had a UTI that had to be cleared up with antibiotics. There was nothing I could not do myself. I am married but I did not need any help. I started driving after 4 days and went to the grocery store with the wife and pushed the cart. Leg bag was attached. I just wore loose fitting clothes to the hospital and did not take anything to read or play with. Just watched the TV when I was not walking or sleeping. Other than the gas causing bad stomach pain for a couple of days when I tried eating the wrong things, it was pretty easy to deal with. I was up and walking every day first a half a mile and then a mile. It's 4 week out now and I am doing everything I used to do. Been riding the bicycle for the last 2 weeks and taking long walks. I have a weight lifting restriction. 5# last month 10# this month, 20# next month and the wife is watching me like a hawk and enforcing it.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Ross did say that he felt that radiation therapies were about to overtake RP in efficacy the next few years and that RP would likely be left for only the more "difficult" cases." From my discussions with the RO and what I have read I believe this is true. But I also think it will be like the Pony Express. Radiation will become the gold standard for a short while and then gene therapy will come of age. But don't wait for it.

Radiation will become the gold standard for a short while and then gene therapy will come of age. But don't wait for it.

Posts.Title: For Denis and Others trying to Decide on which Treatment

Posts.Content: Tim, I was in the hospital a couple of extra days. One for nausea and then they thought they saw something on my ekg so another day of blood tests and observation. I did not sleep on the recliner but I did sleep on the couch kind of sitting up. Took about 4 days until I felt comfortable laying down in the bed. My stomach was sensitive to most food. A lot of pain, I think from gas. I could drink coconut milk and eat yogurt. It took me 3 days to start eating solid food. No bladder problems and was continent from the time they removed the catheter. I had a UTI that had to be cleared up with antibiotics. There was nothing I could not do myself. I am married but I did not need any help. I started driving after 4 days and went to the grocery store with the wife and pushed the cart. Leg bag was attached. I just wore loose fitting clothes to the hospital and did not take anything to read or play with. Just watched the TV when I was not walking or sleeping. Other than the gas causing bad stomach pain for a couple of days when I tried eating the wrong things, it was pretty easy to deal with. I was up and walking every day first a half a mile and then a mile. It's 4 week out now and I am doing everything I used to do. Been riding the bicycle for the last 2 weeks and taking long walks. I have a weight lifting restriction. 5# last month 10# this month, 20# next month and the wife is watching me like a hawk and enforcing it.

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Looks like these devices have been around for 30 years or so. Does it help men? Here is a quote from webmd. Vaginal or anal electrical stimulation has been tried mostly in women who have urge, stress, and mixed incontinence. There is some research that it can help reduce how often women have incontinence. In men with urinary incontinence after prostate surgery, pelvic floor exercises and anal electrical stimulation did not improve incontinence any more than pelvic floor exercises alone after 8 weeks. Goode PS, et al. (2011). Behavioral therapy with or without biofeedback and pelvic floor electrical stimulation for persistent postprostatectomy incontinence. JAMA, 305(2): 151-159.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by fishinguy I also wonder when I will stop thinking about PCa in that scenario. How long will it take before I kind of forget I even had it? Can that happen, or will it really become something that never seems to go away. Good to here your doing well fishinguy. I don't think I will ever forget. It has been kind of life changing in a lot of ways. John Piper wrote on the eve of his prostate cancer operation in 2006 an article from a Christian point of view called 'don't waste your cancer'. There are a lot of people here that have not let it go to waste and are here helping people almost every day. I am grateful for all of them as I know you are. Take care. Ed

Posts.Title: Where will you be for the eclipse?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Onlyamonk I am new to this site, and have questions regarding whether I am a candidate for focal laser ablation. Am I in the right place? Hello Onlyamonk, Sorry you have to be here but you have found a place with a lot of knowledgeable, friendly and helpful people to try and answer your questions. Focal laser ablation is very new and studies are being done and it looks like most of the people receiving it were in studies. I don't know if anyone here has even had it done but this is an excerpt from a UofC web page that may help. http://www.uchospitals.edu/specialti....html#P37_3957 You may be a candidate for MRI-guided focal laser ablation therapy for prostate cancer if you meet the following criteria: Diagnosed with prostate cancer with a Gleason score of 6 or 7 Have no evidence that cancer has spread to other parts of the body (metastatic disease) Able to undergo treatment in an MRI. This includes having no presence of a metal medical device such as a pacemaker or surgical clips in the body or conditions including kidney disease that may prevent use of contrast dye during the procedure. Evidence of cancer on MRI that corresponds with the biopsy findings If you can post more information about yourself such as the diagnosis you received, psa history. Was a biopsy done to confirm cancer and if so what were the results. Your age. This would give the guys an idea where your at and help in the answers you are looking for. Ed

Posts.Title: Where will you be for the eclipse?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by leach234 I would be interested in your opinion of what you would do under my circumstances now that you have had your cancer treatment and know my circumstances. Do you think I am going about this the right way? I think if you are fully informed what ever choice you make is right. The cure rate statistically is the same for where you are and the guys here will support and tell you all they can. I had surgery and I would not change anything I did. Posts.Content: Gerd, Sounds like everything went the way one would hope and your off to a good start. About leakage. From UCLA http://urology.ucla.edu/workfiles/IM...0-09_final.pdf If your catheter is leaking: •Place a towel or waterproof pad under you to protect your furniture. •You may wrap gauze around the catheter where it enters your body if you have drainage or leakage. Make sure to change the gauze when it feels wet. It is OK if your catheter leaks a little. If you begin to leak a large amount of urine, call your doctor or health care team.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by leach234 I would be interested in your opinion of what you would do under my circumstances now that you have had your cancer treatment and know my circumstances. Do you think I am going about this the right way? I think if you are fully informed what ever choice you make is right. The cure rate statistically is the same for where you are and the guys here will support and tell you all they can. I had surgery and I would not change anything I did. I was fully informed and I think that helps to not have buyers remorse so to speak. Making the choice for me was the hardest part. I think a lot of guys feel that way. But once I made the choice I had peace and went forward.

Posts.Title: How fast does a Gleason 8 prostate tumor grow

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Dave&Barb We just received the path report today, and noticed that one of the samples, a G7(4+3) mentioned "perineural invasion present". Quick bit of research shows some upsetting information, such as "nerve sparing NOT recommended", higher rate for mets, recommendation for surgery PLUS radiation, or radiation PLUS HT. Uro did not mention this on the initial diagnosis phone call, but I imagine he will address this at the appointment. Any thoughts or suggestions on what we should be thinking about or what to ask, will be appreciated. Trying to get our heads around everything, certainly a whirlwind. It's frightening to hear the C word. We've only just been together for 4 years, having lost our spouses both to cancer ten+ years ago. Thank you so much, Barb Barb, Welcome to the forum. I am sorry you have to be here and for your previous losses. Your husbands diagnosis is very similar to mine and nerve sparing was done on one side. The side that was thought to be cancer free. In the end some cancer was on that side and PNI was found in the final report after the operation. There is still debate about the significance of PNI but this 2017 study seems to indicate it raises the seriousness of the cancer diagnosis; http://cebp.aacrjournals.org/content/26/5/719 Conclusions: These data support the hypothesis that perineural invasion creates a microenvironment that promotes cancer aggressiveness. Impact: Our findings suggest that PNI should be a standardized component of histopathologic review, and highlights a mechanism underlying prostate cancer metastasis. The opinion on PNI will probably continue to change as more about it is known. I have not had any radiation or HT therapy since my operation a year ago and it has not been recommended yet. Your doctor might not have mentioned it because like my doctor he wants to wait for the final path report. Anyway, you should ask him about it and get his thoughts. Good you are checking into radiation. There are different type of radiation treatment. I was offered HD Brachy treatment. I suggest you check into it if the RO you meet with does not offer it. One of our forum brothers, SubDenis has just had it and is very satisfied. On another note. That jump in PSA. Was the PSA test given after the DRE? If it was that would account for the rise. Other will chime in to welcome you and give their opinions. They are a great group of guys and gals that hang out here. Take care, Ed

Posts.Title: Perineural Invasion

Posts.Content: Gerd, Sounds like everything went the way one would hope and your off to a good start. About leakage. From UCLA http://urology.ucla.edu/workfiles/IM...0-09_final.pdf If your catheter is leaking: •Place a towel or waterproof pad under you to protect your furniture. •You may wrap gauze around the catheter where it enters your body if you have drainage or leakage. Make sure to change the gauze when it feels wet. It is OK if your catheter leaks a little. If you begin to leak a large amount of urine, call your doctor or health care team.

Posts.Title: Day 5 Post RALP

Posts.Content: I had some mind numbing pain in my stomach in the hospital and for a couple days after I got home. I think it was gas. I had to avoid any food or drink that would bring it on. Not bad enough to bring tears but I had to stand up and hang onto something for a minute or two 3 or 4 times a day when it flared up. I have had flu symptoms that were more prolonged in stomach pain. Also had a uti that made the catheter a pain for the last couple days it was in when I moved wrong. The incisions and operation area were a non issue. No pain pills were needed. It was all in all easier than I expected.

Posts.Title: Perineural Invasion

Posts.Content: I am going to guess your talking about PSA density, PSAD. ng/ml/cc. The question I have is how accurate they are in calculating prostate size. I was told mine was anywhere from 28 to 32 when in fact from the final pathology report it was 50. Is my case unusual or do they get this wrong a lot? Hopefully the doctors using this to make these decisions are better at calculating this than I experienced. My psa was 14-15 so this did not matter in my case.

Posts.Title: where you briefed on HDR BT prior to choosing TX

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by wtdedula He said there is nothing wrong with my bladder and frequency of urination too should improve with time - this is a comment that surprised me but also encouraged me. I would absolutely love to be able to sleep throughout the whole night and if I am able to someday soon, that will be the second biggest benefit to me (besides getting rid of cancer) of having Prostate surgery. Tim Tim, I am 5 months out now and even though I did not have continence problems I did not hold a very large volume. It is only now getting back to normal. Right after the cath was removed the volume was OK. Then it got worse until now. I think it has to do with the healing and scare tissue that keeps the bladder from expanding easily at first. If that makes any sense. It sounds like your on a normal track. Ed

Posts.Title: 3 months following surgery - update

Posts.Content: You will probably run out of questions long before a half hour and he can explain what he wants to do in less than 5 minutes. Since you have researched this most of your questions will probably be about him and his track record. Your wife is right about it being important how you feel about the doctor as much as his pedigree. When I went in for the biopsy not knowing anything I asked the doctor if this comes back positive what are my prospects? Will I live 10 years? He looked at me very serious and said "our goal here is to cure people". That is all he said and I had a lot of trust in him after that. Don't know why. Just the way he said it maybe.

Posts.Title: Large prostate means lower risk?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mik1999 Just taking an informal poll to see how others handled the same situation. I know there is nothing wrong with keeping things confidential. Ahh, just curious. I don't know what prompted you to get PSA checks at such an early age but it's good you did. You caught it early and have every reason to expect a cure. I hope your surgery is being done by someone with a lot of experience. I think a minimum 300 operations is what the guys here recommend. You want the best you can get to try and minimize side effects. You can ask any questions you want and we will try to answer the best we can. Good luck. Ed

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis \I am told these symptoms might be a bit more intense after round two.. Sounds like the first round went well and no matter what the second one brings it should all be behind you for spring. But if your playing golf you probably don't have spring, or at least not as dramatic a change as here. I just shoveled 4 inches of snow off the walk and driveway. Good luck, take care Ed

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed - Do you tell boss/coworkers?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Mik1999 Did you disclose everything or keep things private? Mik1999, Welcome to the forum. To answer your question. I revealed to my co-workers my Dx. I had great conversations with them and I received great support. I heard many stories of their family members who had gone through what I was going through. Maybe some will even get tested that would not because of my story. I am curious. Since you say you don't want to reveal your situation to your co-workers which is your right, why do you want to know what we did? There is nothing wrong with your decision.

Posts.Title: Decision Made - RALP scheduled

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis Today I was reading a few new guys posts and the wonderful feedback they were receiving. I reflected on my journey to date and was struck by the difficulty I had and time it took to get to a decision. What factors affected my decision? I did not like either surgery or HD brachy. + EBRT which were my main 2 options. As I got closer to the surgery date I started thinking of changing to the radiation but I realized when I analyzed why I wanted to change I was just wanting to kick the can down the road and if it was radiation I was getting ready to do I would have felt the same apprehension. That was a little piece of my journey. The good thing is when you get this done all this anxiety will be gone and you can get on with your life. You will be forever changed but I think for you, you will make it better than ever. Some have accused this site of being pro surgery. I would say it is not. It just is not hostile to surgery and to some that is the same as being for it. They are wrong. We cheer on and support the radiation options also but we also point out what we have learned about it and don't sugar coat it. Take care denis God bless and enjoy the holidays. Ed

Posts.Title: 3rd day Post RALP

Posts.Content: The study was for one doctors patients. There does not seem to be much value in such a study other than for the one doctor. This study has more information: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4659370/ Jonathan I. Epstein,a,b,c,* Zhaoyong Feng,b Bruce J. Trock,b,c and Phillip M. Pieroraziob Final version: http://www.europeanurology.com/artic...168-6/fulltext Quotes from the study: "Almost 20% of RP cases have tertiary patterns. A needle biopsy can sample a tertiary higher Gleason pattern in the RP, which is then not recorded in the standard GS reporting, resulting in an apparent overgrading on the needle biopsy." "There are fewer studies examining the incidence of downgrading. Three studies looked at downgrading from GS 8−10 to ≤7 with results ranging from 29%, 40%, to 56% [15,17,22]. In the current study, 51.3% of GS 8 biopsies had a lower grade at RP. In cases with biopsy GS 9–10, 31.1% had RP grades ≤7. Moussa et al. recorded a 7.3% incidence of downgrading from GS 3 + 4 = 7 to GS ≤6 [14]. In the current study, 12.0% of cases diagnosed as 3 + 4 = 7 on biopsy had GS 5–6 at RP. One explanation for these cases is that tangentially sectioned small glands of pattern 3 on biopsy were overgraded as Gleason pattern 4. Alternatively, in some cases the assigned biopsy GS may have been accurate with such small foci of Gleason pattern 4 in the RP that it was either not recorded or unsampled deeper within the paraffin block. In cases with borderline GS 5–6 versus GS 3 + 4 = 7 on biopsy, it is probably better to diagnose the case as GS 6 because potential undergrading due to sampling error is more acceptable than overgrading due to grading error."

Posts.Title: Peach pits

Posts.Content: I found this article informative. If you know someone who has been discouraged to get a PSA test (my 52 year old brothers doctor told him he did not need it last year) this is the reason why and you can tell them that has now changed. I know many here already know what this task force did in 2012 and hopefully their change will reverse the trend they started. https://www.forbes.com/sites/benjamindavies/2017/04/11/new-official-prostate-cancer-screening-guidelines-announced-too-little-too-late/#379655a7442b Excerpt date 4/11/2017 This morning the U.S. Preventive Services Task Force (USPTF) scraped the congealed egg from its face with a dull knife. Once done, they changed the 2012 recommendations for PSA screening for prostate cancer from a D (discourage the use of this service) to a C (offer or provide this service only if other considerations support the offering or providing the service) for all men aged 55-69. If you are over 70 then you still get the D recommendation. Confused? Government language can do that. I read it as the following: get a PSA test if you understand the benefits and risks of screening for prostate cancer. There is a modest benefit for some and a modest risk for some--proceed with eyes wide open. In effect, decades of successful prostate cancer screening and treatment have been wiped out in five years since the 2012 USPTF decision. A remarkable change in events that has no parallel in public health history. It was buffoonery of the highest order in 2012; today marks a terse shift back to normalcy. Public health students will be studying this debacle for decades. American men will be dying from it for years.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by derbyrobert but it is his lack of human concern which worries me. Robert Wojciechowski B.Sc. M.Sc. C.Psychol. A.F.B.P.S Consultant Chartered Clinical Psychologist What does that mean, "his lack of human concern". Was he involved in volunteer programs and now he is not? Or is he just not expressing the same feelings of concern that he had before? He just went through a life changing experience. Mortality is now very real and the brevity of life comes into sharp focus. I don't think anyone goes through this without some change. And it probably is not yet over in his mind. You are not certain of a cure for years. You might have to give him some time to get it sorted out. Most guys would say that the experience though has made them a better person overall. Strange but true.

Posts.Title: Great news...with a catch!

Posts.Content: Hi Alan, Glad you found our forum but sorry you had to. That is an aggressive form you have there but if treated you can expect to die from something other than prostate cancer. You said you wanted the prostate removed but I would suggest you look into radiation if you have not already and especially HD Brachy. Having two major surgery's would be tough and you didn't say how urgent your kidney removal is but I don't believe you want to put off treating this form of prostate cancer for long and radiation treatment would limit it to one surgery. HD Brachy does involve surgery to place the seads but it is nothing like a radical prostatectomy. You should be definitely talking to an RO and probably an MO to figure out what to do. I am sure other will be talking to you here. They are a great group. Take care Ed

Posts.Title: Peach pits

Posts.Content: Jeremy, I have had some pains that I did not have before since the operation. Neck, back etc. Most have been worked out through exercises now. I have had frozen shoulder and there were exercises like put a rope over a pulley in the basement and pull the arm up gradually for a couple of weeks to fix it. But I would see a physical therapist to get evaluated for the type of treatment/exercises you need so you don't damage it further. If it is just a frozen shoulder it won't usually get better by itself. You will just adapt to it.

Posts.Title: Pain post op, after keyhole removal of my cancerous prostate on 4 July 2017

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by GMJJ Our local surgeon (who is chief of staff at the center) told us he has performed "hundreds" since 2009, but as another forum member pointed out, over an 8 year span that really isn't a lot. My surgeon hadn't down thousands but it was over a thousand. It was not a major cancer center either. More of a heart surgery center. It all turned out OK. If "hundreds" is 800 in 8 years that is 2 a week, every week. More than enough. If 200 or 300 maybe not that much. You might want to nail that number down. My uro offered to get me in touch with former patients but I did not take him up on it. I figured that I would only talk to success stories anyway but in retrospect it might have be a good idea if offered. Some people don't think it is important to like your doctor but for me life is too short to deal with doctors I don't like or who are jerks. I can find a doctor just as good or better than them that I can talk to and have good information exchange. I don't need the stress. Get there for those 2'nd opinions and make sure you have a good conversation with the radiation oncologist. Radiation has been shown to have good results with more aggressive cancers as you are dealing with (4+3) and is worth serious consideration. Just know that whatever he decides is right for him and keep going forward. I am sure you two have a lot of years ahead of you. Ed

Posts.Title: Sticky: What I Need to Know About SBRT & IMRT

Posts.Content: Thanks ASA. I posted from the source material. I was not sure you saw the edit to your post. I think this should be OK for the rules. https://www.santishealth.org/prostat...prostatectomy/ Having spent a week in Seoul visiting Professor Rha In June 2016, I performed the UK’s first robotic Retzius-sparing radical prostatectomy on the 4th of July, and the UK’s first laparoscopic Retzius-sparing radical prostatectomy three days later. To date, I have completed 20 Retzius-sparing cases and the results look very similar to those previously published for the technique: 100% of patients were either pad free (80%) or used one small safety liner per day (20%) at 4 weeks following surgery. By contrast, my last 100 conventional, non-Retzius results (which are considered to be excellent), 22% of patients were either pad free (12%) or used one small safety liner per day (10%) at 4 weeks following surgery. Potency results are awaited but the early results also look much better than following conventional surgery. Clearly, to go from 22% to 100% shows remarkable validation for this technique, and I look forward to sharing more of my results in the future. There is 1 year follow up link in the article. Not having the same results here in the states at Henry Ford Hospital though. It was suggested in the original article that the technique may be hard to learn. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/29225060 CONCLUSIONS: Amongst patients with clinically low-intermediate risk PCa randomized to anterior ('Menon') or posterior ('Bocciardi') approach RARP, differences in urinary continence seen at 3 months were muted at 12 months follow-up, while sexual function recovery, postoperative complications and biochemical recurrence rates were comparable 1-year postoperatively. Was fascinating reading.

Posts.Title: Back home

Posts.Content: Rooster, The foley was not too much bother but took your advise and it is even less bother now. Thanks. A problem I had was the Statlock stabilizer they put on me. From day one the arrow was pointing down. I guess someone thought that was flow direction. But it is not. It is supposed to be turned to point to the cath. It will not lock in properly if pointed down. Just a friction fit that will come loose. When the hospital called on a follow up I gave them some constructive advise that their nurses get retrained and learn how to set up these devices. I almost never complain but a lot of people just assume the hospital has it set up right and thats how it should be done. Does not give one confidence to walk around the block if it is only being held there by a friction fit and the leg straps. Anyway onces I went to the Statlock site and read their PDF it all made sense. Again, thanks for the advice. Ed

Posts.Title: Back home

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by bigalcalbisque This whole experience has changed my outlook dramatically, I don't feel like I am afraid of anything anymore. I hope that lasts! If you came through this with that thought it will last. On one of my first posts I mentioned a co-worker gave me a small sailboat when they found out what I was facing. Guys got cancer, lets give him a sailboat. But that boat kept me busy getting it ready for the day I would be physically able to sail it. I have never sailed in my life and the clubs lessons were all over for this year. So I went out about 3 weeks ago in fairly calm wind and started teaching myself to sail. Of course I read a lot also. Ok, third time out today and the wind is 15 gusting to 25. I was a little afraid to try it until I told myself ' look what you just went through and your not going to let a little water scare you or be afraid of making a fool of yourself in front of all these real sailors'. I went out and did it. And fairly well according to people who saw me. On my way back I stood up on the bow to throw a line to the wife and a gust came up, blew the boat over and me into the water. My pfd popped me up and I flipped the boat back upright and looked at the wife and we both started laughing. Not afraid anymore.

Posts.Title: 2 Days After Mr Roboto

Posts.Content: Had the surgery as planned on the 28'th. Got back home yesterday. Had planned to go home on the 29'th but a couple of things came up. Blood sugar went high. Then EKG had a strange reading that took them a day of testing to make sure nothing was wrong. I also could not eat anything without getting huge pain in my gut. I finally tried yogurt with fruit and granola and that was OK. So I am eating plain yogurt and fruit and drinking unsweetened Coconut milk till I get back to normal. Other than that the surgery after effects, pain etc are really nothing thats bothers me. Easier than I thought. The doctor from what he saw and checked he didn't think the cancer had not left the prostate. But we will know for sure when the report comes back. It was nerve sparing on the left side and he went wide on the right side due to the biopsy report to be safe. Walking around the block for exercise. Not a problem. Catheter not really a problem. So all in all It's good. Daughter came over this morning to mow the lawn and other family are gathering tomorrow to grill some burgers and dogs. I am really blessed. Thank you everyone for posting the experiences. It truly helped me.

Posts.Content: That's good news Tim, It's been 2 weeks since I had my PSA check and your post reminded me I did not know my results yet. I called and after waiting for 20 minutes the lady came back and told me it was .1. I asked her is that .1 or <.1. She said it was good and anything less than .25 was good. I said no, its not good and I asked again if there was a less than sign ahead of that .1 and she said "oh yeah there is a less than sign in front of it". I told her to get that posted up in the portal so I could see it. Anyway I guess if your BG was high enough it might put you in a deeper sleep than normal. Also a couple of drinks before sleep could relax you a bit too much but it sounds like your on an average path and doing will. Thanks for the update. Take care. Ed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nhlsir54 Any words of wisdom would be helpful. Nhsir, Sorry your going through another cancer episode but you have found a good place to talk to men who have been through this. Surgery has it's down sides. But so does radiation. A recent study out of Toronto says this: CONCLUSIONS: Radiotherapy for prostate cancer is associated with an increased risk of overall and prostate cancer-specific mortality compared with surgery based on observational data with low to moderate risk of bias. These data, combined with the forthcoming randomized data, may aid clinical decision making. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26700655 Another quote from https://www.cancer.org/latest-news/s...treatment.html Two years and 5 years after treatment, men in the prostatectomy group were significantly more likely than those in the radiation group to report urinary leakage and erectile dysfunction. But the problems increased in both groups over time, and 15 years after treatment, the likelihood of having these side effects was similar between the 2 groups. At 15 years, almost all the men reported having erection problems – 87 percent in the prostatectomy group and 93.9 percent in the radiation group. So you see, any treatment choice we need to make to save our lives can take a toll and we just don't know for sure how it will affect us. Unfortunately the decision is more subjective than most of us are comfortable with. But anyway; As to your situation. You are young and your 3+3 may need more investigation because you could be a candidate for Active Surveillance. If not active surveillance than with treatment you have every reason to expect a cure since you have caught this fairly early. I will let others speak to that and other tests you may want to ask for to figure out what to do. There are guys on AS here and others that are very knowledgeable. But obviously not medical personal. Your medical team should be your main go to people for direction. People here though would normally suggest you get a second opinion on that biopsy at a minimum. Again, Welcome and stay tuned for more input. Ed

Posts.Content: Hi, Re: Ketones. To add to what Tim said. Has he changed his diet to not include many carbs? Maybe not on purpose as a low carb diet, but changed it anyways. Is he eating well? If he is not feeling like eating and skipping meals his body will start burning fat to get the energy it needs and produce Ketones.

Posts.Title: What to ask at time of biopsy results?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by SubDenis However, the ease of BT has caught my attention. HD Brachy + EBRT or surgery were the two finalists I was deciding between so I understand its appeal and success rates, though I wouldn't use the word 'ease' to describe any of the treatments we are faced with. They all have their challenges and effects. Even AS. Check it out with your usual due diligence and make sure the person doing the procedure is experienced. I think you will do good with whatever you decide. Ed

Posts.Title: Review with Uro imminent

Posts.Content: I don't think the secondary cancer concern is outdated. I found this when I looked into it. This is a study of men 1992 to 2010. From a U of M article in 2014. "when researchers looked at patients who received external beam radiation therapy, they found these patients were estimated to be 70 percent more likely to be diagnosed with a rectal cancer and 40 percent more likely for bladder cancer than the general public." "Prostate cancer has an excellent prognosis. But because patients typically survive a long time, it raises concerns about the risk of second cancers," says study author Elizabeth J. Davis, M.D., a fellow at the U-M Medical School. "Long-term survivors who have undergone treatment with radiation and their physicians should be careful to monitor for symptoms of bladder and rectal cancer."

Posts.Title: What to ask at time of biopsy results?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by cog6 Got my catheter out yesterday and that is nothing less than wonderful. Cog, Sounds like your on a path the doctors strive for and we all hope for. Myself, I felt like I could do more than I actually could and had to cool it. Took me a few months to get back the stamina. I still don't sleep like a rock like I used to, 6 months later, but it is getting better. Everybody is different and you will have your own unique experience. Things change during the healing. Pee flow rates (pee flow rates?) can change, pains pop up here and there etc etc, but everyday should get better and you will probably even forget about it for stretches at a time. Congrats and take care, Ed

Posts.Title: Anterior Fat Pad - Huh?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by keeptrying I'm 63 years old and recently got a PSA reading of 6.4 (17.2% free) with a negative DRE as per my very experienced Primary Care Physician. Values 17 months earlier were 3.4 and 18.5%, and all prior results were 3.6 or lower. I don't know the PSA density. I'm REALLY hoping to avoid a biopsy if possible. Welcome keeptrying to the forum, It is ok to hope to avoid a biopsy. Just don't try to avoid one if needed, obviously. Your free PSA indicates a 20% chance of cancer. But a free psa of .25 is the trigger point that would suggest a biopsy is the next step for you IF other reasons cannot explain the PSA rise. BPH, prostatitis, urinary tract infection, etc. So take it one step and a time and if a biopsy is needed so be it. But I think a second PSA test will probably be done and the doctor will look at the other conditions that can cause a rise in PSA before you get there. For most a biopsy is a mere bother but there are risks like all invasive procedures. Here a a discussion of the risks of biopsy. The data is varied, like most things pCA. Risks of biopsy  Although early reports indicated that prostate biopsies very rarely (<1 percent) caused complications (eg, bleeding, infection) serious enough to require hospitalization [132], subsequent studies suggest both higher rates of infectious complications and that the rate of infectious complications may be increasing over time [133-136]. Hospitalization rates for infectious complications in these studies have ranged from 0.6 to 4.1 percent [135]. Infectious complications can lead to sepsis, which can very rarely lead to death. A modeling study, assuming a biopsy mortality rate of 0.2 percent [137], concluded that prostate cancer screening could be associated with a net increased overall mortality, particularly under the conditions that biopsy rates are high and screening is relatively ineffective [138]. However, other studies have suggested much lower mortality rates following biopsy [135]. Population-based studies include an analysis of United States Medicare data that found a mortality rate of 0.3 percent in the 30 days following biopsy; this was actually 70 percent lower than the 30-day mortality in a comparison population not undergoing biopsy [133]. An analysis of registry data from Canada found a 30-day mortality rate of 0.09 percent [134]. Randomized trials with follow-up on 1147 biopsies [139], and 10,474 biopsies [140], reported no biopsy-related deaths. Other potential harms from prostate biopsy (eg, bleeding or urinary obstruction) are discussed elsewhere. (See "Prostate biopsy", section on 'Complications'.) Prostate biopsy can also lead to anxiety and physical discomfort [141]. Among 116 men undergoing biopsy in the Rotterdam screening study, 55 percent reported discomfort with the procedure, including 2 percent who had pain persisting longer than one week. Being diagnosed with prostate cancer is psychologically distressing, but even patients with a negative biopsy result may be distressed [142,143]. Chronic anxiety can follow a negative prostate biopsy because this apparently favorable result cannot completely rule out prostate cancer given the relatively high false-negative biopsy rate [144]. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/sc...rostate-cancer Don't stress and keep doing the next steps required. Take care, Ed

Posts.Title: How to choose a urologist who could do multiparametric MRI fusion biopsy if needed?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Nhlsir54 Any words of wisdom would be helpful. Nhsir, Sorry your going through another cancer episode but you have found a good place to talk to men who have been through this. Surgery has it's down sides. But so does radiation. A recent study out of Toronto says this: CONCLUSIONS: Radiotherapy for prostate cancer is associated with an increased risk of overall and prostate cancer-specific mortality compared with surgery based on observational data with low to moderate risk of bias. These data, combined with the forthcoming randomized data, may aid clinical decision making. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/26700655 Another quote from https://www.cancer.org/latest-news/s...treatment.html Two years and 5 years after treatment, men in the prostatectomy group were significantly more likely than those in the radiation group to report urinary leakage and erectile dysfunction. But the problems increased in both groups over time, and 15 years after treatment, the likelihood of having these side effects was similar between the 2 groups. At 15 years, almost all the men reported having erection problems – 87 percent in the prostatectomy group and 93.9 percent in the radiation group. So you see, any treatment choice we need to make to save our lives can take a toll and we just don't know for sure how it will affect us. Unfortunately the decision is more subjective than most of us are comfortable with. But anyway; As to your situation. You are young and your 3+3 may need more investigation because you could be a candidate for Active Surveillance. If not active surveillance than with treatment you have every reason to expect a cure since you have caught this fairly early. I will let others speak to that and other tests you may want to ask for to figure out what to do. There are guys on AS here and others that are very knowledgeable. But obviously not medical personal. Your medical team should be your main go to people for direction. People here though would normally suggest you get a second opinion on that biopsy at a minimum. Again, Welcome and stay tuned for more input. Ed

Posts.Title: New prostate cancer diagnosis for lymphoma survivor

Posts.Content: I had a TRUS biopsy. There was an initial shot that wasn't too bad (little pinch!). Of the 12 cores only one toward the end I felt. The rest were just pressure and a click noise. I had no pain or complications afterwards. All in all I have had more discomfort during a teeth cleaning procedure. I have read about people that had a hard time but it wasn't clear if the doctor was at fault or it was just something about them. I never hesitated to have the biopsy. The consequences of letting it go further if there was problem kinda made the choice for me. But my psa was a lot higher than yours. If it was me I would get a 2nd opinion.

The consequences of letting it go further if there was problem kinda made the choice for me. But my psa was a lot higher than yours. If it was me I would get a 2nd opinion.

Posts.Content: I don't think the secondary cancer concern is outdated. I found this when I looked into it. This is a study of men 1992 to 2010. From a U of M article in 2014. "when researchers looked at patients who received external beam radiation therapy, they found these patients were estimated to be 70 percent more likely to be diagnosed with a rectal cancer and 40 percent more likely for bladder cancer than the general public." "Prostate cancer has an excellent prognosis. But because patients typically survive a long time, it raises concerns about the risk of second cancers," says study author Elizabeth J. Davis, M.D., a fellow at the U-M Medical School. "Long-term survivors who have undergone treatment with radiation and their physicians should be careful to monitor for symptoms of bladder and rectal cancer."

Posts.Title: First post and very stressed

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by keeptrying I'm 63 years old and recently got a PSA reading of 6.4 (17.2% free) with a negative DRE as per my very experienced Primary Care Physician. Values 17 months earlier were 3.4 and 18.5%, and all prior results were 3.6 or lower. I don't know the PSA density. I'm REALLY hoping to avoid a biopsy if possible. Welcome keeptrying to the forum, It is ok to hope to avoid a biopsy. Just don't try to avoid one if needed, obviously. Your free PSA indicates a 20% chance of cancer. But a free psa of .25 is the trigger point that would suggest a biopsy is the next step for you IF other reasons cannot explain the PSA rise. BPH, prostatitis, urinary tract infection, etc. So take it one step and a time and if a biopsy is needed so be it. But I think a second PSA test will probably be done and the doctor will look at the other conditions that can cause a rise in PSA before you get there. For most a biopsy is a mere bother but there are risks like all invasive procedures. Here a a discussion of the risks of biopsy. The data is varied, like most things pCA. Risks of biopsy  Although early reports indicated that prostate biopsies very rarely (<1 percent) caused complications (eg, bleeding, infection) serious enough to require hospitalization [132], subsequent studies suggest both higher rates of infectious complications and that the rate of infectious complications may be increasing over time [133-136]. Hospitalization rates for infectious complications in these studies have ranged from 0.6 to 4.1 percent [135]. Infectious complications can lead to sepsis, which can very rarely lead to death. A modeling study, assuming a biopsy mortality rate of 0.2 percent [137], concluded that prostate cancer screening could be associated with a net increased overall mortality, particularly under the conditions that biopsy rates are high and screening is relatively ineffective [138]. However, other studies have suggested much lower mortality rates following biopsy [135]. Population-based studies include an analysis of United States Medicare data that found a mortality rate of 0.3 percent in the 30 days following biopsy; this was actually 70 percent lower than the 30-day mortality in a comparison population not undergoing biopsy [133]. An analysis of registry data from Canada found a 30-day mortality rate of 0.09 percent [134]. Randomized trials with follow-up on 1147 biopsies [139], and 10,474 biopsies [140], reported no biopsy-related deaths. Other potential harms from prostate biopsy (eg, bleeding or urinary obstruction) are discussed elsewhere. (See "Prostate biopsy", section on 'Complications'.) Prostate biopsy can also lead to anxiety and physical discomfort [141]. Among 116 men undergoing biopsy in the Rotterdam screening study, 55 percent reported discomfort with the procedure, including 2 percent who had pain persisting longer than one week. Being diagnosed with prostate cancer is psychologically distressing, but even patients with a negative biopsy result may be distressed [142,143]. Chronic anxiety can follow a negative prostate biopsy because this apparently favorable result cannot completely rule out prostate cancer given the relatively high false-negative biopsy rate [144]. https://www.uptodate.com/contents/sc...rostate-cancer Don't stress and keep doing the next steps required. Take care, Ed

Posts.Title: OT - Communist health care - they have that right

Posts.Content: Thank you everyone for your comments. And Chuck I use the MrEd moniker as a sign in to important places like this. It was my fathers name he was called by his friends down in Florida where he had a biker bar for many years and it is kind of my way to honer him. But I get the talking horse thing. I guess most all here remember that show. I kinda like the connection. I decided to go with the surgery and it is scheduled for the 28, next Wednesday. The HD Brachy and radiation sounded good also. It was a hard choice. The RO said he was sure whatever I chose would work out good for me. I am planning for the future. A co-worker and her husband gave me a small sailboat, A Mirror dinghy. Her father had radiation therapy 10 years ago and she thought I would enjoy sailing. I have only sailed catamaran type boats a little and am looking forward to giving this a try. I live by oodles of lakes including the big ones. I should have done this sooner. Probably not this year though given the situation. But who knows. I was amazed at how many people have been touched by prostate cancer. I was quite open about it with friends and co-workers and when I told them what I had been diagnosed with they came out of the woodworks with their personal stories. I told my little brother who is 52 and 6 inches taller than me, about my diagnosis and asked him if he had a PSA test when he had his last physical and blood work done a couple of months ago. He said he would check and when he asked his doctor the doctors reply was. "what for?" He explained why and the doctor said OK. Don't know the results yet but it seems to me a lot of people are going to be hurt by this trend in medicine to downplay the PSA tests.. Glad my PCP decided I better get one. I guess the insurance companies don't like the biopsy costs because of false positives, but still, is this only a numbers game? I will post back here after the operation. In the mean time I have a boat to get ready. Ed

Posts.Title: Appointment with Robot tomorrow

Posts.Content: First off I want to say thanks to all that take their own time to post here. I have been reading the site now for the last few week and it has helped me so much to understand PCa, what I should be asking and doing. The attitudes and friendliness I have seen is rare and I am pretty sure I am in a better state of mind because of all of you here. I am married, grown kids and just retired on Monday, Been planned for 6 months. I have met with the Uro and RO and discussed options. The Uro talked to me about surgary. He is the person I was refereed to and has done over 1000 DaVinci procedures The RO talked to me about Brachy plus IMRT. I will meet with both doctors of them on Monday to answer some additional questions and make a decision. I think where I am at it's pick my poison and see what happens. Neither option is a clear winner for me though I am leaning to surgery, a lot of which is because of my confidence in the doctor, despite the 34% confined partin table stat. The hospital system is Beaumont in southeast MI. I live about 3 miles from there. Any comments, suggestions are of course welcome. Oh, and yes this was my first PSA test. Ed

Posts.Title: Three consecutive 0.0 PSA's ... No More Lupron, WooHoo!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bholmes Not sure what to expect so any words would be greatly appreciated! Bholmes, For most of us the biopsy was just uncomfortable and after the initial needle "pinch" we did not feel much. Like any medical procedure where they are poking needles into you, especially through the rectum, there is a chance of infection. Severe enough to end back up in the hospital so don't delay calling your doctor if you have a fever or other symptoms that should be listed on an instruction sheet given to you before you leave the doctors office. You will have blood in the urine and semen for days afterwards. That was high at 14 but that drop to 9 is not something cancer will normally do. It could be an infection or maybe a combination of cancer and an infection causing havoc with the prostate. And as Rob pointed out there are false negatives. In other words the needles missed finding anything on the first try. Stay positive and take it one step at a time and don't assume the worst. Good chance it may well not be cancer. Ed

Posts.Signature: DOB 1955 Went for physical on 3/30/17 and had blood work done 3/31/17 PSA 15.1 Refered to Urologist. 4/5/17 DRE Negative 4/7/17 PSA 14.1 4/19/17 TRUS Negative 5/1/17 Biopsy 12 cores RLB 3+4 30% RM 3+3 6% RLM 4+3 90% RLA 4+3 5% Left side negative 5/26/17 Cat scan Negative 6/7/17 Full body bone scan, Negative Decipher score .62 high risk RALP scheduled 6/28/17 Final pathology report 7/28/17 Prostatic adenocarcinoma with mucinous differentiation Gleason score 4+3 involving both lobes limited to the prostate Percentage involved by tumor 5% EPE -, SVI -, LVI -, LN -, PNI+, Margins - Pathologic stage pT2 N0 PSA 8/4/2017 <0.1 PSA 10/27/2017 <0.1 PSA 1/26/2018 <0.1 PSA 4/27/2018 <0.1 PSA 10/2018 <0.1 PSA 4/2019 <0.1
Posts.Title: Three consecutive 0.0 PSA's ... No More Lupron, WooHoo!

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Bholmes Not sure what to expect so any words would be greatly appreciated! Bholmes, For most of us the biopsy was just uncomfortable and after the initial needle "pinch" we did not feel much. Like any medical procedure where they are poking needles into you, especially through the rectum, there is a chance of infection. Severe enough to end back up in the hospital so don't delay calling your doctor if you have a fever or other symptoms that should be listed on an instruction sheet given to you before you leave the doctors office. You will have blood in the urine and semen for days afterwards. That was high at 14 but that drop to 9 is not something cancer will normally do. It could be an infection or maybe a combination of cancer and an infection causing havoc with the prostate. And as Rob pointed out there are false negatives. In other words the needles missed finding anything on the first try. Stay positive and take it one step at a time and don't assume the worst. Good chance it may well not be cancer. Ed
